abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second National
            Agricultural Research Project (NARP II) in India are as
            follows: overall outcome of the project was rated
            satisfactory, and the performance of the Bank and the
            Borrower were also rated as satisfactory. Some of the
            lessons learned from the project are: 1) the concept of a
            decentralized research system, started under NARP and
            carried on under NARP II, based on a uniform system where
            research has become the responsibility of Zonal Research
            Station (ZRSs) of State Agricultural University (SAUs)
            conducting adaptive research in local agro-ecological zones,
            is sound and its continued development is essential if the
            diverse farming systems in India, particularly the rainfed
            systems, are to benefit from new technologies; 2) generally,
            most ZRSs, but not sub-stations, have adequate facilities
            and sufficient numbers of scientific staff. However, the
            nature of the farming systems and their great diversity
            makes it necessary to have more multidisciplinary teams
            working in an inter-disciplinary context with more emphasis
            placed on financial viability of technologies, marketing
            potential, diversification (broad-basing) of farm production
            and relevance of technologies to farmers circumstances. The
            SAUs need to give higher priority to horticulture,
            livestock, fisheries and agro-forestry research; and 3) the
            project's implementation benefited from strong
            expertise in agricultural research of the Bank's
            Resident Mission staff who supervised the project.
